{{good article}} {{NCAATeamSeason |Mode = Basketball |Year = 2010â11 |Prev year = 2009â10 |Next year = 2011â12 |Team = Temple Owls |Image = TUOwls logo.png |logo_size = 150px |university = Temple University |Conference = Atlantic 10 Conference |ShortConference = A-10 |CoachRank = |APRank = |Record=26â8 |ConfRecord=14â2 |HeadCoach=[[Fran Dunphy]] |AsstCoach1=[[Dave Duke]] |AsstCoach2=[[Matt Langel]] |AsstCoach3=[[Shawn Trice]] |StadiumArena=[[Liacouras Center]] |BowlTourney=NCAA Tournament |BowlTourneyResult=Round of 32 }} {{2010â11 Atlantic 10 men's basketball standings}} The 2010â11 [[Temple Owls]] men's basketball team (the Owls) represented [[Temple University]] in the [[2010â11 NCAA Division I men's basketball season]]. The team played their home games at the [[Liacouras Center]], which has a capacity of 10,206. The Owls were in their 29th season as a member of the [[Atlantic 10 Conference]]. In the [[2009â10 Temple Owls men's basketball team|previous season]], Temple Owls gained a record of 29â6 and reached the [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]]. The team returned three starters from the previous season, but leading scorer Ryan Brooks and point guard Luis Guzman left, having graduated. They were replaced by new players Aaron Brown, Anthony Lee, and Jimmy McDonnell and graduate student transfer Dutch Gaitley. In the off-season, other Atlantic 10 coaches predicted that Temple Owls would win the league.
Temple Owls finished the season with a 26â8 record. Among the highlights of the year was an upset of #10 [[2010â11 Georgetown Hoyas men's basketball team|Georgetown]] on December 9, in coach [[Fran Dunphy]]'s 400th victory. In addition, [[Lavoy Allen]] became Temple Owls' all-time leading rebounder in a 66â52 rout of [[Saint Joseph's Hawks men's basketball|Saint Joseph's]]. Allen snatched 12 boards to pass Temple Owls' radio analyst [[Johnny Baum]]'s 1,042 career rebounds. The Owls' 14â2 mark in Atlantic 10 play earned them a two seed in the [[2011 Atlantic 10 Men's Basketball Tournament]], where they lost in the semifinals to [[2010â11 Richmond Spiders men's basketball team|Richmond]].
The team earned an [[at-large bid]] to the [[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]] as a seven seed, and defeated [[2010â11 Penn State Nittany Lions men's basketball team|Penn State]] in the round of 64 on a last-second shot by guard [[Juan Fernandez (basketball)|Juan Fernandez]]. The win ended Dunphy's 11-game losing streak in the NCAA Tournament, the longest on record. Temple Owls' season ended with a double overtime loss to [[2010â11 San Diego State Aztecs men's basketball team|San Diego State]] in the round of 32. After the season, Allen was selected for the All-Atlantic 10 First Team, [[Ramone Moore]] was selected for the All-Atlantic 10 Second Team, Fernandez was an All-Atlantic 10 Third Team selection, and Scootie Randall was recognized as an All-Atlantic 10 Honorable Mention. Allen was drafted by the [[Philadelphia 76ers]] in the second round of the [[2011 NBA Draft]].
==Preseason== [[File:WTP B07 Audrey 2.jpg|thumb|left|Temple played their home games at the Liacouras Center in Philadelphia]] In 2010â11, the Temple Owls men's basketball team were in their 29th season as a member of the [[Atlantic 10 Conference]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://a.espncdn.com/media/pdf/091115/temple.pdf|title=Temple|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|accessdate=November 12, 2010}}</ref> Since 1997, the team has played their home games at the [[Liacouras Center]], which has a capacity of 10,206.<ref>{{cite news|first=Mike|last=Kern|url=http://www.philly.com/dailynews/sports/20101111_AT_A_GLANCE_1.html?viewAll=y|title=Temple basketball at a glance|accessdate=November 12, 2010|date=November 11, 2010|work=[[Philadelphia Daily News]]|publisher=Philly.com}}</ref> In their [[2009â10 Temple Owls men's basketball team|previous season]], an Atlantic 10 Preseason Poll predicted that Temple Owls would finish fifth in the conference, tied with [[Duquesne Dukes men's basketball|Duquesne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/atl10/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/MBBPre0910.pdf|title=2009â10 Atlantic 10 Men's Basketball Preseason All-Conference Teams|date=October 22, 2009|work=[[CBS Sports]]|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=November 14, 2010}}</ref> Despite the low expectations, the Owls were tied with [[Xavier Musketeers men's basketball|Xavier]] atop the [[2009â10 Atlantic 10 Conference men's basketball season|Atlantic 10 standings]] with a 14â2 conference record, and won their third straight [[2010 Atlantic 10 Men's Basketball Tournament|Atlantic 10 tournament]] title.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=300730218|title=Temple holds off Richmond rally to claim another A-10 championship|accessdate=November 14, 2010|date=March 14, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> The team drew a five seed in the [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]], where they lost to 12 seed [[Cornell Big Red men's basketball|Cornell]] in the first round, 78â65, and finished with a record of 29â6.<ref>{{cite news|first=Fred|last=Goodall|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2010/mar/19/no-12-seed-cornell-dominates-temple-78-65/|title=No. 12 seed Cornell dominates Temple 78â65|accessdate=November 14, 2010|date=March 19, 2010|work=[[San Diego Union-Tribune]]|publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com}}</ref> Head coach [[Fran Dunphy]] was rewarded with a contract extension on May 5, 2010 and will stay with Temple Owls until the 2017â18 season.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/news/story?id=5165873|title=Dunphy, Temple Owls agree to extension|accessdate=November 14, 2010|date=May 5, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
Before the 2010â11 season, Temple Owls men's basketball team lost two starters from the previous year to graduation: Ryan Brooks and Luis Guzman. Brooks was the team's highest scorer, with an average of 14.3 points per game, and averages of 4.2 rebounds and 2.3 assists per game. In his final season, he was selected for the all-conference second team and finished his career with 1,225 points, the 31st highest in Temple Owls' history.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.owlsports.com/news/2010/8/3/MBB_0803105605.aspx?path=mbball|title=Ryan Brooks Signs Professional Contract with German Club |accessdate=November 15, 2010|date=August 3, 2010|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref> Guzman was the Owls' starting point guard, leading the team in assist-to-turnover ratio at 2.07 and averaged 4.9 points, 4.2 rebounds, and 3.2 assists per game. He was the team's captain and earned a degree in Bachelor of Business Administration in three and a half years.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.owlsports.com/news/2010/8/27/MBB_0827105919.aspx?path=mbball|title=Luis Guzman Signs Pro Contract with Slovakian Club|accessdate=November 15, 2010|date=August 27, 2010|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref> [[Walk-on (sports)|Walk-on]] forward Rafael DeLeon also graduated.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.owlsports.com/news/2010/3/6/MBB_0306100645.aspx?path=mbball|title=#16/20 Temple Wins A-10 Regular Season Championship|accessdate=November 15, 2010|date=March 6, 2010|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref>
Two players left Temple Owls voluntarily: sophomores Chris Clarke and Carmel Bouchman. Clarke [[Redshirt (college sports)|redshirt]]ed in 2009â10 after transferring from [[Pensacola Junior College]], transferred again to [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] [[Morehouse College]]. Bouchman appeared in nine games and tallied a total of 12 minutes and two points before returning to [[Tel Aviv, Israel]].<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/news/story?id=5517651|title=Two players decide to leave Temple|accessdate=November 15, 2010|date=August 31, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> [[Lavoy Allen]], a first team all-conference selection and the team's leading rebounder at 10.7 rebounds per game. Allen briefly played with the [[2010 NBA Draft]], but returned to Temple Owls for his senior season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.owlsports.com/news/2010/5/8/MBB_0508100709.aspx|title=Lavoy Allen Withdraws Name From NBA Draft|accessdate=November 15, 2010|date=May 8, 2010|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref> Forward Craig Williams had foot surgery and did not play that season.<ref>{{cite news|first=Keith|last=Pompey|url=http://articles.philly.com/2011-03-05/sports/28655928_1_lavoy-allen-senior-power-big-five|title=Allen ready for his final home game as an Owl|date=March 5, 2011|accessdate=June 8, 2011|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|publisher=Philly.com}}</ref>
On October 21, 2010, the Owls were voted by other Atlantic 10 coaches as the preseason favorite to win the league, receiving 19 first place votes. Allen was selected for the All-Conference First Team and Defensive Team, while [[Juan Fernandez (basketball)|Juan Fernandez]] was selected for the second team.<ref name=preseasonfaves/> Allen was listed on the preseason [[Wooden Award|Wooden]] and [[Naismith Award]] 50-man watchlist.<ref name=wooden/><ref name=naismith/> [[Jay Bilas]] of ESPN named Temple Owls the third best team in the Atlantic 10, behind [[Xavier Musketeers men's basketball|Xavier]] and [[Dayton Flyers men's basketball|Dayton]]. He cited Allen's summer experience on the USA select team and the development of Michael Eric as factors for a successful season.<ref>{{cite web|first=Jay|last=Bilas|authorlink=Jay Bilas|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/notebook/_/page/notebooksummershootaround100818/atlantic-10|title=Summer Shootaround: Atlantic 10|accessdate=November 23, 2010|date=August 18, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
===Recruiting=== ====Incoming signees==== Anthony Lee, a [[center (basketball)|center]] from [[Eustis, Florida]], joined Temple Owls on September 26, 2009, becoming the first member of the Owls' recruiting class.<ref name=Scout10>{{cite web|title=Scout.com College Basketball Recruiting Commits|url=http://scouthoops.scout.com/a.z?s=75&p=9&c=8&cfg=bb&toinid=351&yr=2010|work=[[Scout.com]]|publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]|accessdate=April 11, 2011}}</ref> The Maryland native transferred from Eustis High School to West Oaks Academy after his junior year. As a senior, he averaged 23.0 points, 14.0 rebounds, and 3.0 blocks per game while winning MVP honors from the Sunshine Independent Athletic Association. ESPN ranked him the #38 center in his class.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.owlsports.com/roster.aspx?rp_id=4606&path=mbball|title=2010â11 Men's Basketball Roster: #3 Anthony Lee|accessdate=June 8, 2011|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref> Lee picked Temple Owls over scholarship offers from [[USC Trojans men's basketball|Southern California]], [[Georgia Bulldogs men's basketball|Georgia]], and [[Seton Hall Pirates men's basketball|Seton Hall]].<ref name=tworecruits>{{cite news|url=http://www.owlsports.com/news/2009/11/20/MBB_1120095426.aspx?path=mbball|title=Men's Basketball Signs Two Recruits|accessdate=June 8, 2011|date=November 20, 2009|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref> After undergoing surgery for a [[herniated disc]], Lee [[redshirt (college sports)|redshirted]] the season.<ref>{{cite news|first=Keith|last=Pompey|url=http://articles.philly.com/2011-01-14/sports/27028230_1_owls-liacouras-center-redshirt|title=Owls redshirt freshman forward|date=January 14, 2011|accessdate=June 8, 2011|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|publisher=Philly.com}}</ref>
On November 2, [[small forward]] Aaron Brown of [[Newark, New Jersey]] signed with the Owls.<ref name=Scout10/> He posted per-game averages of 17.6 points, 4.0 rebounds, 4.5 assists, and 3.0 steals in his senior campaign at [[St. Benedict's Preparatory School|St. Benedict's Prep]]. Brown was a New Jersey All-Prep First Team selection in 2010 and participated in the Jordan Brand Classic Regional.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.owlsports.com/roster.aspx?rp_id=4604&path=mbball|title=2010â11 Men's Basketball Roster: #22 Aaron Brown|accessdate=June 12, 2011|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref> He chose Temple Owls over [[Harvard Crimson men's basketball|Harvard]], [[Miami Hurricanes men's basketball|Miami (Fl.)]], [[Penn Quakers men's basketball|Penn]], [[Boston College Eagles men's basketball|Boston College]], and [[Florida State Seminoles men's basketball|Florida State]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Andy|last=Vasquez|url=http://www.northjersey.com/sports/93835734_Brown_s_choice_is_Temple.html|title=Hackensack's Aaron Brown finds a hoops home at Temple|date=May 15, 2010|accessdate=June 13, 2011|work=[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Record]]|publisher=NorthJersey.com}}</ref>
Small forward Jimmy McDonnell, from [[Jackson, New Jersey]], joined the team on August 11, 2010.<ref name=Scout11>{{cite web|title=Scout.com College Basketball Recruiting Commits|url=http://scouthoops.scout.com/a.z?s=75&p=9&c=8&cfg=bb&toinid=351&yr=2011|work=[[Scout.com]]|publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]|accessdate=June 13, 2011}}</ref> In his senior season at [[Jackson Memorial High School]], McDonnell averaged 13.9 points, 6.5 rebounds, and 4.0 blocks per game as Jackson Memorial compiled a 16â8 record. McDonnell was selected for the first team all-Division in the A-Shore Conference, and was the most valuable player at the WOBM Holiday Classic.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.owlsports.com/news/2010/8/19/MBB_0819100612.aspx|title=Jimmy McDonnell Signs Scholarship Letter to Play Men's Basketball|date=August 19, 2011|accessdate=June 13, 2011|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref> McDonnell was originally headed to Division II [[UMass-Lowell]], but after a strong performance at the West Virginia HoopGroup JamFest, he drew the attention of Owls coach Fran Dunphy. McDonnell redshirted the season to add bulk to his frame.<ref>{{cite news|first=Mike|last=DeCourcy|url=http://aol.sportingnews.com/ncaa-basketball/story/2010-08-20/strong-summer-earns-prep-forward-scholarship-to-temple|title=Strong summer earns prep forward Jimmy McDonnell scholarship to Temple|date=August 20, 2010|accessdate=June 13, 2011|work=[[Sporting News]]}}</ref>
Dutch Gaitley was granted a one-time transfer exception by the NCAA and was eligible immediately, instead of sitting out the customary season. The forward graduated in three years from [[Monmouth University]], earning his [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 2009. At Temple, Gaitley pursued a masterâs degree in sports administration. A native of [[Haverford, Pennsylvania]], he was a 2006 graduate of [[Archbishop John Carroll High School (Radnor, Pennsylvania)|Archbishop Carroll High School]]. In 88 games at Monmouth, he averaged 2.3 points and 4.1 rebounds per game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.owlsports.com/news/2010/10/14/MBB_1014102026.aspx|title=Dutch Gaitley Added To Men's Basketball Roster|date=October 14, 2010|accessdate=June 14, 2011|work=[[Temple Owls]]|publisher=[[Temple University]]}}</ref>

====2011â12 team recruits==== The sole member of the Owls' 2011 recruiting class is Will Cummings, a [[point guard]] from [[Jacksonville, Florida]] who committed on September 4, 2010.<ref name=Scout11/> He averaged 18.1 points, 8.1 assists, 4.0 steals per game as a senior at [[Providence School]], in addition to carrying a 4.0 [[grade point average]]. The Jacksonville Times-Union named him the high school boys basketball player of the year.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jeff|last=Elliot|url=http://m.jacksonville.com/sports/basketball/2011-04-16/story/all-first-coast-best-come-providences-will-cummings|title=All-First Coast: Best to come for Providence's Will Cummings|date=April 16, 2011|accessdate=June 14, 2011|work=[[Jacksonville Times-Union]]}}</ref> Cummings drew attention from [[Stanford Cardinal men's basketball|Stanford]], [[Miami Hurricanes men's basketball|Miami (Fl.)]], and [[Boston College Eagles men's basketball|Boston College]], but chose Temple because of their winning tradition.<ref>{{cite news|first=Keith|last=Pompey|url=http://articles.philly.com/2010-11-28/sports/24953352_1_temple-owls-acc|title=Temple recruit Will Cummings a true student-athlete|date=November 28, 2010|accessdate=June 14, 2011|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|publisher=Philly.com}}</ref>

==Season== ===Preconference season=== Temple Owls started their season with a 62â56 home win against [[Seton Hall Pirates men's basketball|Seton Hall Pirates]] on November 12. Seton Hall last led with 8:15 in the first half, off a Herb Pope jump shot to made the score 20â17. The Owls went on a 17â0 run to close the half. They led by up to 16 with 4 minutes and 16seconds left in the game, but Seton Hall scored the next 12 points to cut their deficit to four. Despite retaining most of their players from the 2009-2010 season, when they were the eighth-highest scoring team in Division I at 80.1 points per game, Seton Hall was held to 30 percent shooting by Temple Owls' defense.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303160218|title=Consistent defense lifts Temple over Seton Hall|accessdate=November 23, 2010|date=November 12, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> [[Juan Fernandez (basketball)|Juan Fernandez]] led Temple Owls with 12 points, and Rahlir Jefferson recorded his first double-double at 10 points and 10 rebounds. Owls player [[Lavoy Allen]] sat out much of the game with foul trouble.<ref>{{cite news|first=Keith|last=Pompey|title=Temple defeats Seton Hall, 62â56|date=November 13, 2010|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]}}</ref> The Owls won their next game against [[Toledo Rockets men's basketball|Toledo]] 82â49. All five starters scored above nine, and Micheal Eric was the highest scorer, with 14 points.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303180218|title=Micheal Eric leads five players in double-digit scoring for Temple|accessdate=November 24, 2010|date=November 14, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
Over Thanksgiving weekend, the Owls traveled to [[Lake Buena Vista, Florida]] to participate in the [[Old Spice Classic]]. Temple Owls suffered their first loss of the season on November 25, falling to [[California Golden Bears men's basketball|California]] 57â50. The Golden Bears went on a 16â1 run late in the second half to seal a victory.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303290025|title=Cal uses late 16â1 run to advance in Old Spice Classic|accessdate=December 12, 2010|date=November 25, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> The next day, Temple Owls recovered to beat [[2010â11 Georgia Bulldogs men's basketball team|Georgia]] 65â58. Scootie Randall had a career-high 18 points for the Owls, including 15 in the first half. Rahlir Jefferson's converted a three-point play with 41.4 seconds left, securing a win for Temple Owls.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303300218|title=Georgia stays close but No. 20 Temple wins at Old Spice Classic|accessdate=December 12, 2010|date=November 26, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> In the Old Spice Classic consolation game, Temple Owls lost to [[2010â11 Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball team|Texas A&M]] 54â51. Texas A&M took a 51â50 lead when B.J. Holmes scored with 18.5 seconds left. Juan Fernandez then missed an open jumper that would have given Temple Owls the lead. "We've got to shoot the ball better. Our defense is pretty solid. We've got a chance to be a good basketball team," said Temple Owls' coach [[Fran Dunphy]] after the game.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303320218|title=Aggies notch upset of Owls in Old Spice Classic consolation |accessdate=December 12, 2010|date=November 28, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
The team's next challenge was the [[Central Michigan Chippewas men's basketball|Central Michigan Chippewas]], which Temple Owls handled 65â53. The Owls were losing 31â41 with 16:35 left in the game, but then scored the next eight points. Temple Owls permanently took the lead off a Lavoy Allen layup with 9:30 remaining. Juan Fernandez notched 18 points led the Owls, and Allen had a double-double of 13 points and 10 rebounds.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303352117|title=Temple 65, Cent. Michigan 53|accessdate=December 12, 2010|date=December 1, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> In the teams' first meeting since 2006, Temple Owls knocked off [[2010â11 Maryland Terrapins men's basketball team|Maryland]] 63â61. Despite trailing by 15 at halftime, Maryland staged a comeback led by [[Terrell Stoglin]], who had 12 of his 16 points in the second half. James Padgett dunked with 1:49 left to tie the game at 56. Afterwards, Lavoy Allen completed a three-point play, and Khaliff Wyatt stole a Dino Gregory pass to put Temple Owls in the lead permanently. The Owls outrebounded the Terrapins 42â32, and [[Ramone Moore]] scored 16 points, leading the team.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303352117|title=Temple 64, Maryland 61|accessdate=December 13, 2010|date=December 5, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
On December 9, Temple Owls matched up against [[2010â11 Georgetown Hoyas men's basketball team|Georgetown]]. Fran Dunphy earned his 400th career victory, as his Owls upset the tenth-ranked Hoyas 68â65. At their first home game in almost a month, Temple Owls took an early 6â0 lead and did not trail the entire game. They led by 11 in the first half, and a [[backdoor cut]] to Ramone Moore put the Owls up 39â32 at the break. The Hoyas manage to tie the game at 56 when [[Chris Wright (basketball, born 1989)|Chris Wright]] sunk a pair of [[free throws]]. A [[three-pointer]] from Moore and a putback shot from Rahlir Jefferson enabled Temple Owls to take a 61â56 lead. A hook shot by Georgetown's Julian Vaughn cut the Hoya deficit to one with less than a minute remaining, but Hollis Thompson missed a layup that would have given the Hoyas the lead. Jefferson grabbed the rebound and then netted two foul shots, and a last-second halfcourt shot by [[Austin Freeman]] went over the backboard. Temple Owls' fans rushed the court after the buzzer, as Georgetown suffered their first loss of the year. Moore shot 12-for-18 from the floor for a career-high 30 points. Dunphy congratulated his team's defensive effort, holding the Hoyas to 44 percent shooting, and said, "it's all about these guys. They're all great players and great people."<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303430218|title=Ramone Moore scores 30 to lead Temple Owls past No. 10 Georgetown|accessdate=December 14, 2010|date=December 9, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
The Owls then defeated three [[Mid-American Conference]] teams: [[Akron Zips men's basketball|Akron]], [[2010â11 Northern Illinois Huskies men's basketball team|Northern Illinois]], and [[Ohio Bobcats men's basketball|Ohio]]. On December 12, behind Micheal Eric's 16 points, Temple Owls routed Akron 82â47. At halftime, the Owls led 40â15 after shooting 63 percent in the first half.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303460218|title=Temple 82, Akron 47|accessdate=January 2, 2011|date=December 12, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> Temple Owls shot 53.4 percent from the field in an 84â74 win over Northern Illinois. Lavoy Allen had 22 points and Ramone Moore had 21 in the contest.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303520218|title=Xavier Silas' 27 not enough as NIU loses to Temple|accessdate=January 2, 2011|date=December 18, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> Rahlir Jefferson's career-high 18 points led Temple Owls past Ohio 76â65 for the Owls' sixth consecutive victory.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303560195|title=Temple 76, Ohio 65|accessdate=January 2, 2011|date=December 22, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
When Temple Owls squared off against #7 [[2010â11 Villanova Wildcats men's basketball team|Villanova]] on December 30, it marked the first time since 1988 that two [[Philadelphia Big Five]] teams ranked in the [[Associated Press]] poll met. The Owls held star guard [[Corey Fisher]] to five points, but his backcourt mates [[Corey Stokes]] and [[Maalik Wayns]] tallied 24 and 21 points, respectively, to give Villanova a 78â74 victory. The game was back-and-forth all night, and Temple Owls held a 40â39 lead at the break. Villanova built a 10-point lead in the second half, but the Owls went on a 13â0 run to take a three point lead. With 2.3 seconds left, Lavoy Allen hit a three to cut the Wildcats' lead to 76â74, but Wayns sealed the win with a pair of free throws. Allen scored 22 for Temple Owls, and Juan Fernandez had 20 points.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=303640222|title=Corey Stokes leads Villanova past Temple Owls in Philadelphia showdown |accessdate=January 10, 2011|date=December 30, 2010|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
===Conference season=== To begin the conference season, the Owls won against [[Fordham Rams|Fordham]] 70â51 at the [[IZOD Center]]. Fordham last won a conference game on January 28, 2009, but Temple Owls had a 27â22 deficit in the first half. However, a balanced offensive attack, led by Juan Fernandez and Ramone Moore's 15 points each, helped Temple Owls to take the lead. Michael Eric scored his first collegiate double-double with 14 points and 11 rebounds, and Lavoy Allen was the fourth starter to score in double figures, with 12 points.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310052230|title=Temple 70, Fordham 51|accessdate=January 26, 2011|date=January 5, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> On January 6, starting point guard Juan Fernandez bruised his knee in practice and missed the January 9 game against [[2010â11 Saint Louis Billikens men's basketball team|Saint Louis]]. Despite shooting 30.6 percent from the field, the Owls won 57â53 behind Ramone Moore's 15 points. Temple Owls was behind 41â32 with 10:13 remaining, then went on an 11â2 run. Moore scored five consecutive points to break a tie at 49, giving the Owls a lead. The Billikens missed all seven three-point shots against the Temple Owls defense.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310090218|title=Temple 57, Saint Louis 53|accessdate=January 26, 2011|date=January 9, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> Fernandez also missed the January 12 game against [[St. Bonaventure]], but the Owls defeated the Bonnies nonetheless, 83â55. Ramone Moore led all five starters in double-digit scoring with 19 points. The team shot 30 of 59 from the field and 9 for 21 from three-point land.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310120218|title=No. 23 Temple dominates St. Bonaventure|accessdate=January 27, 2011|date=January 12, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
Temple Owls' first loss in conference play was 78â66 against [[Duquesne Dukes men's basketball|Duquesne Dukes]], despite the return of Juan Fernandez. The Owls began the game by trailing 22â2, missing their first 14 shots. Temple Owls scored their first [[field goal (basketball)|field goal]] at the 8:18 mark of the first half, and shot 17 percent in the first half. Duquesne shot 67 percent in the first half en route to a 40â23 halftime lead. In the second half, the Owls scored the first six points, but the Dukes went on an 8â2 run from which Temple Owls could not recover. Ramone Moore contributed 18 points to lead the Owls.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310152184|title=Cold-shooting Temple dropped by streaking Duquesne|accessdate=January 27, 2011|date=January 15, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> Temple Owls recovered with a 75â56 out-of-conference win against [[Philadelphia Big Five]] team [[Pennsylvania Quakers men's basketball|Penn]]. Khalif Wyatt scored a career-best 27 points, Ramone Moore added 12 points and Lavoy Allen scored 10 points and six blocks.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310190218|title=Temple 73, Penn 56|accessdate=January 27, 2011|date=January 19, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
[[2010â11 Xavier Musketeers men's basketball team|Xavier]] defeated Temple Owls 88â77 on January 22, extending their in-conference home-court winning streak to 35, surpassing Temple Owls' 34-game in-conference consecutive home victories for the longest in Atlantic 10 history. Former Xavier player [[Brian Grant]] had his jersey retired at halftime, and the team wore [[throwback uniforms]] in his honor. Grant gave the Musketeers a pep talk prior to the game, and Xavier opened an early 16â8 lead. Scootie Randall scored Temple Owls' first 10 points, hitting five out of his first six shots. The Owls took their only lead of the half 29â28 off of a three by Randall. In the second half, the teams traded baskets before Xavier went on a 10â0 run. Randall led Temple Owls on an 11â1 run to tie the game at 66, knocking down two [[fastbreak]] layups and a three-point shot, and finished with a career-high 28 points. The Owls took their final lead 69â68 off a Khalif Wyatt three-pointer with 5:30 to go. Afterwards [[Tu Holloway]] hit a scoop shot and Mark Lyons had a layup and a steal to give Xavier a 75â69 advantage that they maintained. Holloway scored 21 points and Lyons 19 to score the most points against Temple Owls in the season.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310222752|title=Xavier 88, Temple 77|accessdate=February 6, 2011|date=January 22, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
Khalif Wyatt, who replaced Juan Fernandez after Fernandez had continuing knee problems, was key in Temple Owls' 76â67 win over [[Charlotte 49ers men's basketball|Charlotte]]. He scored 17 points, collected six [[assist (basketball)|dimes]], and grabbed six rebounds. Ramone Moore added 16 points, Lavoy Allen recorded a double-double (15 points and 11 rebounds), and Scootie Randall contributed 14 points.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310260218|title=Temple 76, Charlotte 67|accessdate=February 9, 2011|date=January 26, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> On January 29, Temple Owls defeated city rival [[Saint Joseph's Hawks men's basketball|Saint Joseph's]] 72â54. Scootie Randall led Temple with 17 points.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310292603|title=Temple 72, Saint Joseph's 54|accessdate=February 11, 2011|date=January 29, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> In their next game, Temple Owls won against [[La Salle Explorers men's basketball|La Salle]] by 71â67. The Owls had a 61â47 lead with 3:17 left, but Aaric Murray led a late Explorers comeback as he connected on two three-point shots. Khalif Wyatt scored 18 points for the Owls.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310332325|title=Temple 71, La Salle 67|accessdate=February 12, 2011|date=February 2, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
The Owls defeated [[Rhode Island Rams men's basketball|Rhode Island]] 80â67 on February 5. Scootie Randall scored 27 points as Temple Owls shot 53.2 percent from the field.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310360218|title=Temple 80, Rhode Island 67|accessdate=March 27, 2011|date=February 5, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> Against [[Fordham Rams|Fordham]], Temple Owls' 25-point lead was cut to three before winning 77â66. Brandon Frazier of the Rams drained a three-pointer with 13:17 left to trail 53â50, but they would get no closer. Ramone Moore scored 22 points to lead the Owls. Lavoy Allen left the game in the second half with an injury to his right ankle.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310400218|title=Temple fights off Fordham's second-half surge to win fifth straight|accessdate=March 27, 2011|date=February 9, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> Allen missed the following game against [[Dayton Flyers men's basketball|Dayton]], but Temple Owls managed a 75â63 victory nonetheless, sparked by Ramone Moore's 26 points. Temple Owls missed their first seven shots, allowing Dayton to stay in the game. However, Moore hit a three-pointer to start an 11â2 run to put the Owls ahead 18â12. Their defense held Dayton to 37 percent shooting, and Temple Owls maintained their lead. After the game, Dayton coach [[Brian Gregory]] said: "...they're [Temple Owls] one of the best passing teams not just in the league, but in the country."<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310432168|title=Temple Owls' defense pressures Dayton to 37 percent shooting|accessdate=March 29, 2011|date=February 12, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
Before the game against [[2010â11 Richmond Spiders men's basketball team|Richmond]], Temple Owls announced that starting center Micheal Eric was unavailable for the season with a right [[patella]] injury. Lavoy Allen returned and Temple Owls ended the Spiders' eight game road winning streak, scoring 73â53. Ramone Moore scored 24 points. Juan Fernandez registered 20 points off of 9â10 shooting. Temple Owls controlled the game with a 16â0 run in the second half and shot 56 percent on the game.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310480218|title=Ramone Moore's 24 points helps No. 25 Temple Owls end Richmond's road success|accessdate=March 30, 2011|date=February 17, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> Lavoy Allen became Temple Owls' all-time leading rebounder in a 66â52 rout of [[Saint Joseph's Hawks men's basketball|Saint Joseph's]]. Allen snatched 12 boards to surpass Temple Owls radio analyst [[Johnny Baum]]'s career 1,042 rebounds. Ramone Moore's 17 points led the team, and Allen scored 14 points to go along with his milestone rebounds. Temple Owls' forward Scootie Randall was unavailable, having a foot injury.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310510218|title=No. 25 Temple cruises past city-rival St. Joseph's|accessdate=March 30, 2011|date=February 20, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> The Owls traveled to [[Cameron Indoor Stadium]] to play against top-ranked [[2010â11 Duke Blue Devils men's basketball team|Duke]] in a nonconference game. Temple Owls lost to the Blue Devils 78â61, as [[Kyle Singler]] led Duke with 28 points. Lavoy Allen scored 17 points and had 13 rebounds for Temple Owls, but Duke increased their lead against the Owls with a second half run.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310540150|title=Kyle Singler ends scoring slump to lead No. 1 Duke past No. 24 Temple|accessdate=April 1, 2011|date=February 23, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
Temple Owls missed 16 of their first 18 shots against [[George Washington Colonials men's basketball|George Washington]], trailing by 20â8. Lavoy Allen then took control of the team, scoring 10 consecutive points; at halftime the core was 26â23. In the second half, the Temple Owls defense held the Colonials to two points over the last 11:22, and Temple Owls won 57â41. Allen contributed 19 points and 16 rebounds, while Khalif Wyatt scored 14 points.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310570045|title=Temple closes out romp of George Washington with 19â2 spurt|accessdate=April 2, 2011|date=February 26, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> Juan Fernandez's 19 points helped Temple Owls defeat [[UMass Minutemen men's basketball|UMass]] 73â67, in the Owls' first overtime game. Down four at halftime, Temple Owls tied the game at 65 with 48 seconds left off a free throw by Ramone Moore. Fernandez had a chance to win the game in regulation, but his layup with 1 second left was blocked by UMass's Sampson Carter. In overtime, T.J. DiLeo hit a layup with 4:20 remaining that gave Temple Owls the lead.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310610113|title=Temple 73, Massachusetts 67|accessdate=April 3, 2011|date=March 2, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> In Temple Owls' regular season finale, the team earned a 90â82 win against [[La Salle Explorers men's basketball|La Salle]], behind Lavoy Allen's career-high 24 points.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310640218|title=Temple 90, La Salle 82|accessdate=April 3, 2011|date=March 5, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
===Postseason=== In the [[2011 Atlantic 10 Men's Basketball Tournament]], Temple Owls received a two seed by virtue of a 14â2 conference record and earned a [[bye (sports)|bye]] into the quarterfinals. Due to [[La Salle Explorers men's basketball|La Salle]] beating [[St. Bonaventure Bonnies|St. Bonaventure]] in the first round, Temple Owls was matched up with La Salle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegebasketball/tournaments/conference/ATL10|title=2011 Atlantic 10 Tournament|accessdate=April 3, 2011|work=[[CBS Sports]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}}</ref> The Owls won the game 96â76, posting their most points of the season in the process. Five players scored more than nine, and Ramone Moore led the charge with 23 points.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310700218|title=Temple handles city rival La Salle to reach A-10 semifinals|accessdate=April 4, 2011|date=March 11, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref> [[Kevin Anderson (basketball)|Kevin Anderson]] of [[2010â11 Richmond Spiders men's basketball team|Richmond]] scored 22, defeating the Owls in the semifinals 58â54 and ending Temple Owls' ten-game winning streak at [[Boardwalk Hall]]. Ramone Moore hit a layup to push the Owls ahead 54â53 with five minutes left. Richmond grabbed the lead 55â54 at the 3:48 mark as [[Justin Harper (basketball)|Justin Harper]] scored off a putback. Harper finished the game with 18 points and nine rebounds, and was involved in a controversial end-of-game play. With 30 seconds left, Khalif Wyatt attempted a 3-pointer and Harper came down on him, but no call was made. Wyatt proceeded to foul Harper, who hit the deciding free throws. Wyatt had 15 points, while Lavoy Allen added 12 points and 10 rebounds. Juan Fernandez made only 3 of his 17 field goal attempts.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310710218|title=Richmond beats 3-time defending A-10 champion Temple Owls to advance to final|accessdate=April 5, 2011|date=March 12, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
On [[Selection Sunday]], Temple Owls received a seven seed and was due to face [[2010â11 Penn State Nittany Lions men's basketball team|Penn State]] in the [[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]] on March 17 at the [[McKale Center]] in [[Tucson, Arizona]]. The two teams had played each other in a scrimmage in the preseason. They had also met in the [[2001 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]] when the Owls earned a 84â72 victory in the Sweet Sixteen.<ref>{{cite news|first=Dave|last=Zeitlin|url=http://www.csnphilly.com/03/13/11/No-7-seed-Owls-talk-rivalry-eager-to-pla/landing_ncaa.html?blockID=439907&feedID=697|title=No. 7 seed Owls talk rivalry, eager to play PSU|accessdate=April 5, 2011|date=March 13, 2011|work=[[Comcast SportsNet]]}}</ref> Coming into the game, Fran Dunphy had a NCAA tournament record 11-game losing streak, at [[Penn Quakers men's basketball|Penn]] and Temple Owls. "I probably think about it less than others do," said Dunphy, "but you think about it. I would be lying if I said I didn't. But I'm so thrilled for these kids and so thrilled to be in the tournament. We've had a nice run â this particular group, four straight years of going to the NCAA tournament is pretty special."<ref name=latejumper>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310760218|title=Juan Fernandez drains late jumper to lift Temple to third round|accessdate=April 5, 2011|date=March 17, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>
Scootie Randall returned to the Owls and earned the start, although he only played for six minutes and did not score. The game began with hot shooting by Penn State's [[Talor Battle]], who drained three of his first four threes to put the Nittany Lions up 20â11. A 17-point first half by Juan Fernandez helped Temple Owls take a 35â33 lead at halftime. Jeff Brooks, a starting forward for the Nittany Lions, dislocated his right shoulder a minute into the half and sat out the rest of the game. In the second half, there were ten lead changes, and neither team lead by more than four points. Ramone Moore's 15 foot shot with 1:10 remaining pulled the Owls ahead 62â61. In Penn State's ensuing possession, Battle took the ball to the hoop but was blocked by Rahlir Jefferson, and Temple Owls took possession. Fernandez was fouled, and his pair of free throws with 28 seconds left extended the Owl lead to 64â61. With the clock at 12.2, Battle hit a three pointer from beyond the NBA line to tie the game at 64-64. Fran Dunphy called a timeout, and Khalif Wyatt advised Dunphy to draw up a play for Fernandez. Fernandez was double-teamed and was forced to take an off-balance 18-footer. The ball fell through the hoop with four seconds remaining, and Temple Owls won 66â64. Fernandez and Moore finished with 23 points, a season high for Fernandez.<ref name=latejumper/>
Temple Owls' season ended on March 19 with a 71â64 loss to second-seeded [[2010â11 San Diego State Aztecs men's basketball team|San Diego State]] in double overtime. The Aztecs took an 11-point lead in the first half, but Temple Owls recovered. Off a turnover, Lavoy Allen made a seven-footer to tie the game at 54 with 51 seconds left in the second half. Chase Tapley of San Diego State missed a baseline shot at the end of regulation, and the game went into overtime. At the beginning of the first overtime period, Juan Fernandez hit a three-pointer to give the Owls a 57â54 lead. Malcolm Thomas responded with a three-point play to tie the game at 61. Thomas could not hit a shot and the game went into a second overtime. With SDSU maintaining a 69â64 lead, Aztec star [[Kawhi Leonard]] stole the ball from Khalif Wyatt and his uncontested dunk assured his team's victory. Ramone Moore had 17 points, and Allen had 12 points and 11 rebounds in his final game as a Temple Owl.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310780021|title=San Diego State needs two overtimes to put away Temple|accessdate=April 8, 2011|date=March 19, 2011|work=[[ESPN]]|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures}}</ref>

==NBA Draft== In the [[2011 NBA Draft]], the [[Philadelphia 76ers]] drafted Lavoy Allen in the second round with the 50th pick on June 23. Allen became the 32nd Temple player to be drafted and the first since the [[New York Knicks]] selected [[Mardy Collins]] with the 29th pick in 2006. "I am very happy for him," said coach Fran Dunphy. "He accomplished so much as a college basketball player. It is a great reward to be drafted, and to go to the Sixers is icing on the cake."<ref>{{cite news|first=Bob|last=Cooney|url=http://articles.philly.com/2011-06-24/sports/29699408_1_temple-s-allen-lavoy-allen-temple-coach-fran-dunphy|title=Sixers select Temple's Allen|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|publisher=Philly.com|date=June 24, 2011|accessdate=July 6, 2011}}</ref>
